review.title: Online Event Recognition from Moving Vessel Trajectories
review.abstract: We present a system for online monitoring of maritime activity over streaming positions from numerous vessels sailing at sea. It employs an online tracking module for detecting important changes in the evolving trajectory of each vessel across time, and thus can incrementally retain concise, yet reliable summaries of its recent movement. In addition, thanks to its complex event recognition module, this system can also offer instant notification to marine authorities regarding emergency situations, such as risk of collisions, suspicious moves in protected zones, or package picking at open sea. Not only did our extensive tests validate the performance, efficiency, and robustness of the system against scalable volumes of real-world and synthetically enlarged datasets, but its deployment against online feeds from vessels has also confirmed its capabilities for effective, real-time maritime surveillance.

metadata.title: Online Event Recognition from Moving Vessel Trajectories

sections.heading: 5 Empirical Evaluation
sections.text: The mobility tracker for online trajectory detection is developed in GNU C + + and runs entirely from memory to deal efficiently with massive, volatile streaming sites. RTEC8, the complex event (CE) detection component, is used in Prolog9.We have conducted experiments against a real AIS database containing 23GB of AIS messages, which will be used from June 1, 2009 to August 31, 2009 for N = 6,425 ships in the Aegean Sea, the Ionian Peninsula and part of the Mediterranean. Not all ships were activity.7 Source codes are publicly available at http: / / www.dblab.ece.ntua.gr / voic.we we we we https: / / github.com / aartikis / RTEC.

sections.heading: 5.1.1 Performance of online mobility tracking
sections.text: First, we investigate the performance of online sliding event detection using simulations at the initial arrival rate. These experiments were conducted using window specifications with different ranges ω and sliding steps β, and we measure the total time needed to update a window with a fresh batch of raw AIS locations, expire expired ones, detect path events, and report critical points. Then, we calculate averages of these time values across the total number of window instances, determining the cost per film for maintaining and identifying all trajective events in it. Figure 7 plots these average execution costs per window for monitoring the entire fleet. Figure 7 (a) shows that our mobility tracker delivers immediate results for smaller to 2 hours. In the worst case, it takes less than 150ms to detect all critical points per incoming batch of raw positional tuples.

sections.text: In order to assess the quality of these compressed trajectories, we estimated their deviation from the original (i.e., without any raw positions other than those qualified as noise).Deviations can be calculated from the paired distance between synchronized locations from the original and compressed trajectories. If an original AIS point pi was in due course distributed ti as uncritical, then its corresponding temporal threshold p ′ i in the compressed trace can be estimated taking into account linear interpolation along the path linking the two critical points before and after inheritance. For each ship that reported M raw positions, we estimate the root of a square meter error (RMSE) between its original and synchronized sequences of its locations as: RMSE = 15,000 MIS interpolation MD = 15,000 MD = 1 (H, p ′ i) 2which has an RMSE estimate (in meters) per tractor trajectory = 100000orO 1000orO º.

sections.heading: 5.1.4 Compression efficiency
sections.text: In this experiment, we examine the efficiency of our prototype by retaining only important trajectory characteristics as critical points and discarding the rest. To measure the compression ratio achieved by online trajectory tracking, we compare the number of discarded points with the originally transmitted positions per ship. A compression ratio close to 1 means greater data reduction as the vast majority of the original locations are dropped. Figure 12 shows measurements of this ratio with different tolerance angles for detecting changes in the direction of flight. At a slower speed, even minor deviations in the ship's direction can be detected, and thus additional critical points are reported. sections.heading: 5.2.1 Grid partitioning
sections.text: Figure 16 shows the results of a first series of experiments in which we tried to determine the optimal grid granularity / cell size. Starting from a grid of 5 x 5 = 25 cells (with a cell size of 138 x 170 km2), we increased the number of cells along each dimension to 90 x 90 = 8,100 cells (each cell is 9 x 11 km2 wide). Figure 16 (a) shows the average CE detection time in CPU seconds for each different grid. Both the window ω and the slide β are set to 1 hour. The worst grid configuration (90 x 90) is almost two times slower than the best (10 x 10), but in all cases the average time is within the same order of magnitude (and less than 3 seconds). Figure 16 (b) shows the average number of detected CEs for each different grid as a stack diagram. The number of detected CEs shows a decreasing trend from initially detected with the tendency to define the grid type according to the 30, each of which are configuring the grid type in 30.

sections.heading: 5.2.2 Performance under varying window sizes and distributed configurations
sections.text: Next, we will proceed with a more in-depth analysis of RTEC's performance. Figure 17 shows the results of the experiments under different window sizes and distributed configurations. First, we used a single processor to perform CE recognition for all 6,425 vessels, 3,966 ranges and 64 ports. Then, we employed several processors running RTEC in parallel by following a data partitioning scheme. We divided the network that traversed the monitoring area into several sub-grids (groups of adjacent cells) whose number of processors used in parallel was the same. Each processor was responsible for the areas and ports running in, and the vessels running through its assigned sub-grid. We used three distributed settings: performing CE detection on two, four and twelve processors. We made an attempt to evenly distribute the load of MEs among the different processors by exhaustively looking for the best configuration.

sections.heading: 5.2.3 Tolerance to irrelevant events
sections.text: In the experiments presented so far, the input stream consisted of critical MEs, i.e. all events of the input stream were part of the CE pattern and thus activated the detection process. In several applications, however, the CE detection module has to deal with input streams, including several events that are irrelevant to the CE detection module. In order to test RTEC's tolerance to irrelevant input events, we have conducted experiments in which, in addition to critical MEs, we maintain a share of normal events, i.e. those that are not commented as critical by the trajectory detection module. In these experiments, RTEC has to skip the normal events to find the critical MEs that express the CE pattern. Figures 18 and 19 show the results from this group of Ex-periments; the percentage of normal events ranges from 0% (the input stream stream stream) to 100% (the input streams consists of critical MEs).

sections.heading: 5.2.4 Artificially enlarged data streams
sections.text: To further enhance the performance of RTEC, we created extended data streams by inserting additional critical MEs to the real datasets. There are no normal events added to these experiments. For each vessel, we extended its trajectories by a certain number of times (increase factor), but the replicated trajectories were assigned to new vessels that do not exist in the original datasets, opening more than half of the windows. An increase in factor X implies that we have exactly X times as many critical MEs and X times as many ships, compared to the original datasets of 16,000,000 CE terms that do not exist. We varied the increase factor of 20, producing datasets of 128,000 containers that create data of 1,280,000 MEs, data of 1,280,000 containers and 3,280,000 containers. To the best of our knowledge, this is the most comprehensive of CE maritime evaluation techniques.

sections.heading: 6 System Deployment
sections.text: In order to verify its operational capabilities, we have set up our system to monitor the live AIS feeds of ships in the Aegean Sea. Fresh positions are periodically fetched from a database (managed by the University of the Aegean) that receives all the transmitted AIS messages. Each data set retrieved contains only ship identification, geographical position and a time stamp. Currently, fresh inputs are fetched every hour (the sliding step β of the window used in this case), although a different time period can be chosen. Typically, we observed that up to 40,000 fresh data sets per hour can be retrieved, which represents a rather moderate amount of geostreaming data simulated in our empirical validation (see Section 5). As soon as each batch of fresh data arrives, it is consumed by the online mobility tracker to identify all critical points over the course of each ship. The resulting points with their notes are then stored in a QL, which is currently used to verify its operational capabilities.

sections.heading: 7 Summary & Future Work

metadata.abstractText: We present a system for online monitoring of maritime activity over streaming positions from numerous vessels sailing at sea. It employs an online tracking module for detecting important changes in the evolving trajectory of each vessel across time, and thus can incrementally retain concise, yet reliable summaries of its recent movement. In addition, thanks to its complex event recognition module, this system can also offer instant notification to marine authorities regarding emergency situations, such as risk of collisions, suspicious moves in protected zones, or package picking at open sea. Not only did our extensive tests validate the performance, efficiency, and robustness of the system against scalable volumes of real-world and synthetically enlarged datasets, but its deployment against online feeds from vessels has also confirmed its capabilities for effective, real-time maritime surveillance.
